request.prompt:
Du bist ein technischer News-Kategorisierungsassistent mit Fachkenntnissen in IT, K√ºnstlicher Intelligenz, Programmierung, Datenbanken, Arbeitswelt und rechtlichen Themen.
Deine Aufgabe ist es, einen gegebenen Newstext den passenden Kategorien zuzuordnen und f√ºr jede Kategorie eine Relevanz zwischen 1 (nur f√ºr Spezialinteressierte) und 10 (bahnbrechend, f√ºr alle relevant) zu vergeben.

Die Kategorien werden dir als Markdown-Liste vorgegeben.
Gehe folgenderma√üen vor:
1. Analysiere den Newstext.
2. W√§hle alle passenden Kategorien.
3. Vergib f√ºr jede gew√§hlte Kategorie eine Relevanz von 1 bis 10 und begr√ºnde deine Einstufung in einem Satz.

Hier ist die Kategorien-Liste:
- ai
- programming
- databases
- security
- work
- data protection
- copyright

Hier ist der Newstext:
# async behavior in JavaScript


Understanding the async behavior is one of the largest milestone in learning JavaScript. I will give you a very first overview what it is.

<!--more-->

## Procedural code

JavaScript is a language which supports procedural code. What does this mean? It means just the code runs line by line:

```javascript
const variable;
variable = 'example';
console.log(variable);
```

The order what happens is easy to understand:

* The variable gets defined
* It gets assigned with `example`
* It gets logged out to the console

## Event loop and process.nextTick()

But procedural is not all, JavaScript have an event loop. It runs all the code line by line, have a look if there is something next in the event loop, runs this code line by line and so on:

```javascript
console.log('1');
process.nextTick(() => {
  console.log('3');
});
console.log('2');
```

The order the code runs now is not anymore the same order we wrote the lines:

* First `1` gets logged
* Then we add a function to the end of the event loop
* `2` gets logged
* The current loop is over, JavaScript look at the event loop, find and run our
  function we added, `3` gets logged

This is what single threaded and non blocking means. The code run in a single thread, only one part of the code can run at the same time. But its possible to add something to the end of the event loop without blocking the followed code.

## Async behavior

With this in mind we now better understand how async behaves:

```javascript
let user;
db.findUserById(1, record => {
  user = record;
});
console.log(user);
```

We get an `undefined`, because `db.findUserById()` add the callback at the end of the event loop. So the `console.log(user)` runs before the callback which assign user to the record.

### Event driven

In the last example we got in touch with another concept named event driven. The `db.findUserById()` will not run immediately at the end of the event loop, because the database need some time to find the user. It register an event which will be triggered after the¬†user is found. But that doesn't change the async behavior, because also if the database is fast enough to find the user, the callback can't run before the current code in the event loop is finished.

## Summary

It's a very important step to understand async and start to think about which functions runs async and which code runs in which order.

Read more about how to [write async code in JavaScript](/2018/02/02/write-async-code-in-javascript.html).

Asynchronous Programming in JavaScript: A Friendly Guide
========================================================

[

](/@aryan.dev?source=post_page---byline--19bb4e9c48db---------------------------------------)

](/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F_%2Fvote%2Fp%2F19bb4e9c48db&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F%40aryan.dev%2Fasynchronous-programming-in-javascript-callbacks-promises-and-async-await-19bb4e9c48db&user=Aryan&userId=1ad507f8ea0d&source=---header_actions--19bb4e9c48db---------------------clap_footer------------------)

\--

[](/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F_%2Fbookmark%2Fp%2F19bb4e9c48db&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F%40aryan.dev%2Fasynchronous-programming-in-javascript-callbacks-promises-and-async-await-19bb4e9c48db&source=---header_actions--19bb4e9c48db---------------------bookmark_footer------------------)

Listen

Share

In the world of modern web development, asynchronous programming is essential for building smooth, responsive applications. Whether you‚Äôre fetching data from an API, handling user input, or working with timers, JavaScript‚Äôs non-blocking nature allows you to perform tasks in the background without freezing the main thread.

In this article, we‚Äôll dive deep into the key concepts of asynchronous programming in JavaScript ‚Äî **callbacks**, **promises**, and **async-await** ‚Äî and show how to use them effectively to manage non-blocking operations. By the end, you‚Äôll have a solid understanding of how to write cleaner, more efficient code that improves your application‚Äôs performance and responsiveness.

1\. Synchronous Functions in JavaScript
=======================================

At its core, JavaScript executes code synchronously. This means that each line of code runs one after another in a single thread. While this makes code execution predictable, it can lead to performance issues if a particular task (like reading a file or making an API request) takes too long to complete.

Here‚Äôs an example of how synchronous code behaves:

console.log("one");  
console.log("two");  
console.log("three");

Explanation of the code:
------------------------

1.  `**console.log("one")**` prints `**"one"**`.
2.  `**console.log("two")**` prints `**"two"**`.
3.  `**console.log("three")**` prints `**"three"**`.

Since these are synchronous operations, they are executed one after the other in the exact order they appear in the code.

**Output:**
-----------

While this works fine for simple operations, synchronous code can lead to performance bottlenecks. Imagine if one of these lines took several seconds to execute, it would block the entire program, making your application unresponsive to users. This is where asynchronous programming comes in handy.

2\. Asynchronous Functions in JavaScript
========================================

Asynchronous code allows tasks to happen in the background, enabling the rest of the code to continue executing without waiting for the task to finish. This makes JavaScript highly efficient when handling operations like **network requests**, **timers**, or **file reading**.

A basic example of asynchronous behavior in JavaScript is the `setTimeout` function, which delays the execution of a function by a specified amount of time.

Example:
--------

function hello() {  
  console.log("hello");  
}  
  
setTimeout(hello, 2000); // Executes after 2 seconds  
setTimeout(() => {  
  console.log("Hello from ar

Posted on Dec 9, 2023

Mastering Asynchronous JavaScript: A Comprehensive Guide
========================================================

[#javascript](/t/javascript) [#webdev](/t/webdev) [#programming](/t/programming) [#opensource](/t/opensource)

In our increasingly digital world, understanding core web development practices is essential. At the center of this field is 'Asynchronous JavaScript,' a pivotal player in modern web development. This detailed guide aims to demystify Async JavaScript, breaking down its complexities into digestible segments.

JavaScript Async/Await Tutorial ‚Äì Master Asynchronous Programming by Making Ice Cream
=====================================================================================

[Leave a Comment](https://thelinuxcode.com/javascript-async-await-tutorial-master-asynchronous-programming-by-making-ice-cream/#respond) / By [Linux Code](https://thelinuxcode.com/author/linuxcode/ "View all posts by Linux Code") / December 10, 2024

As a senior developer with over 15 years of JavaScript experience, I can definitively say that understanding asynchronous programming is crucial for building modern, real-world applications.

In this comprehensive 4-part tutorial, you will learn:

*   Foundations of synchronous and asynchronous code
*   In-depth guide to callbacks in JavaScript
*   How promises can overcome callback hell
*   Why async/await is the future of asynchronous JavaScript

We will learn these concepts by building an entire ice cream ordering system from scratch! üç¶

So let‚Äòs get started!

Part 1: Synchronous vs Asynchronous Code
----------------------------------------

Before understanding async techniques, we need to first cover the difference between synchronous and asynchronous code execution in JavaScript.

### Synchronous Code in JavaScript

Synchronous code executes line by line in sequential order.

    console.log("Hello");
    console.log("World");

Here "World" will only log after "Hello" executes.

Think of it like ordering food at a restaurant:

1.  Sit down
2.  View menu
3.  Order food
4.  Food arrives
5.  Finish meal
6.  Ask for bill
7.  Pay bill
8.  Leave

Each step needs to completely finish before moving to the next one sequentially.

**Benefits:** Very intuitive code flow and easy to reason about steps.

**Drawbacks**: Blocking operations can halt entire application. For example ‚Äì fetching data from an external API.

### Asynchronous Code

Asynchronous code executes out of sequence through callback functions. Callbacks act as triggers to execute logic independently.

For example:

    console.log("Hello"); 
    
    setTimeout(() => {
      console.log("World");
    }, 2000);
    
    console.log("I execute before World!"); 

Here "World" logs asynchronously after 2 seconds while rest of code keeps running.

In a restaurant analogy:

1.  Sit down
2.  View menu
3.  **Go to self-serve drinks counter while food is prepared**
4.  Order food
5.
